DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: DE LIMA TC;LIMA TC;MONTEIRO-DE-LIMA TC;DELIMA TC;DELIMA, T;De Lima, T.C.M.;de Lima, Thereza Christina Monteiro;Lima, Thereza C. M. de;M. de Lima, T.C.;Thereza C. De Lima;C. DE LIMA, THEREZA;LIMA, THEREZA CHRISTINA MONTEIRO DE;DE LIMA, THEREZA C. MONTEIRO;LIMA, T.C.M.;DE LIMA, TC;DE LIMA. T.C.M.;DE LIMA, THEREZA C.M.;DE-LIMA, T.C.M.;LIMA, THEREZA C.M. DE

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Graduada em Ciências Biológicas - modalidade médica - pela Escola Paulista de Medicina (1977), com Mestrado em Ciências (Fisiologia Geral; 1980) e Doutorado em Fisiologia Humana (Psicofarmacologia) pela Universidade de São Paulo (1991), com pós-doutorado na Yale University School of Medicine (1993-1994), onde trabalhou com Dr. Michael Davis. Fez Estágio Senior no Walter Reed Army Institute of Research, trabalhando no grupo da Dra. Marti Jett, em modelo animal de estresse pós-traumático. É bolsista de produtividade 1C do Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico e Professor titular de Farmacologia da Universidade Federal de Santa Catarina (na instituição desde 1979). Tem experiência na área de Farmacologia, com ênfase em Neuropsicofarmacologia, atuando nos seguintes temas: modulação por neuropeptídeos (taquicininas, nociceptina, nocistatina, NPY) do estresse, ansiedade e depressão, nos últimos anos com um foco em estresse pós-traumático, além da validação da ação central de plantas medicinais.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Graduate in Biology - medical modality at the Universidade Federal de São Paulo (1977), MSc in Physiology at Universidade de São Paulo (1980) and PhD in Pharmacology at Universidade de São Paulo (1991). Full Professor at the Department of Pharmacology, focusing on Neuropsicopharmacology, acting on the following subjects: stress, anxiety, depression, PTSD, neuropeptides and medicinal plants with central action.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Neurobiologia do estresse, ansiedade e depressão. Modulação por neuropeptídeos
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Envolvimento das taquicininas, nociceptina, nocistaina, etc...na modulação do estresse, ansiedade e depressão experimentais. Investigação dos mecanismos neurais e bioquímicos.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Involvement of tachykinins, nociceptin, nociaststin, NPY, etc in the modulation of stress, anxiety and depression disorders. Investigation of the neural and biochemical underlying mechanisms.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Neurobiologia do estresse, ansiedade e depressão. Modulação por neuropeptídeos

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: A Brain Awareness Week (Semana dom Cérebro) é uma campanha global para divulgar os benefícios do estudo do cérebro. A cada ano, no mês de março, universidades, hospitais e outras organizações do mundo todo unem-se durante uma semana para popularizar conhecimentos em neurociências. Esta é uma atividade coordenada pela Dana Alliance for Brain Initiatives e a European Dana Alliance for the Brain.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Characterization of a Mouse Model Simulating Features of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: International Conference on Systems Biology

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Social defeat mouse models of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) were used to simulate human PTSD in animal models. The present study aimed to evaluate the behavioral consequences of the social defeat model of PTSD. Two strains of mice (C57B6 and Balb-C), used as experimental subjects, were kept in a wired mesh box inside the aggressor´s cage (SJL mice ) during 6h for 3 consecutive days and each defeated mouse was randomly placed 3-5 times directly in contact with the aggressor for 2 min or 10 bites. After a 10 days interval, animals were re-exposed to the aggressors for 2 days and their behavior was evaluated immediately after the last direct contact with the aggressor (0h), or after 48h, 1, 2 and 3 weeks in the partition test. Control mice were kept inside the wired mesh boxes without any aggressor in the external cage. Behaviors observed included self-grooming, rearing, partition exploration (sniffing of the plastic mesh partition), digging and risk assessment. Subject mice exposed to aggressor mice exhibited PTSD phenotypes such as freezed motion, aggressor barrier avoidance, startled jumping when in contact with aggressor, decreased-object recognition and tail suspension immobility. Brains were harvested and dissected to 12 different regions that include the amygdale, hippocampus, prefrontal cortex etc. Various organs including the blood were also harvested. Tissues were analyzed using Agilent mouse microarray platform. Microarray data were analyzed and differentially expressed gene were identified. More than 3400 transcripts were differentially regulated in the brain using transcriptome wide expression profiling. Differentially regulated genes were found to be involved in neural tube formation, cerebral cortex cells development and migration, neural crest cell differentiation, neurotransmitter secretion, hippocampus development, cerebral cortex GABAergic interneuron migration, learning and memory, dendrite morphogenesis, nucleus localization, oligodendr

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Social Defeat in Mice: Time Course and Re-Consolidation of Fear and its Relevance to PTSD

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 7th World Congress on Stress

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Animal models can help us understand the mechanisms behind, and identify possible treatment targets for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The present study aimed to evaluate the behavioral consequences of the social defeat model of PTSD. C57/B6 mice, used as experimental subjects, were kept in a wired mesh box inside the aggressor´s cage (SJL mice ) during 6h for 3 consecutive days and each defeated mouse was randomly placed 3-5 times directly in contact with the aggressor for 2 min or 10 bites. After a 10 days interval, animals were re-exposed to the aggressors for 2 days and their behavior was evaluated immediately after the last direct contact with the aggressor (0h), or after 48h, 1, 2 and 3 weeks in the partition test. Control mice were kept inside the wired mesh boxes without any aggressor in the external cage. Behaviors observed included self-grooming, rearing, partition exploration (sniffing of the plastic mesh partition), digging and risk assessment. An avoidance to explore the partition was observed in defeated mice immediately, 48 h, 1 and 2 weeks, but not 3 weeks, after the last social stress session. A reduction on rearing behavior was observed in the defeated mice only immediately after the last social stress session, increasing to control levels at 48h. Social defeated mice also showed an increase in self-grooming behavior. Interestingly, defeated mice did not present a habituation on their locomotor activity as measured by rearing behavior, which could be attributed to an increased arousal level.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Genomic Characterization of a Mouse Model Simulating Features of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 7th World on Stress

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Social defeat mouse models of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) were used to simulate human PTSD in animal models. Mice exposed to aggressor mice exhibited PTSD phenotypes such as freezed motion, aggressor barrier avoidance, startled jumping when in contact with aggressor, decreased-object recognition and tail suspension immobility. Brain tissues were analyzed using Agilent mouse microarray platform. More than 3400 transcripts were differentially regulated using transcriptome wide expression profiling. Differentially regulated genes were found to be involved in neural tube formation, cerebral cortex cells development and migration, neural crest cell differentiation, neurotransmitter secretion, hippocampus development, cerebral cortex GABAergic interneuron migration, learning and memory, dendrite morphogenesis, nucleus localization, oligodendrocyte differentiation, forebrain midbrain boundary formation, and hindbrain and cerebellum structural organization. Phenotypic markers and gene regulations data show validity of social defeat mice as human PTSD models in search of early biomarkers of PTSD.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Reversal of the scopolamine-induced deficits of learning and memory processes by Ilex paraguariensis treatment as evaluated in mice
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Reversal of the scopolamine-induced deficits of learning and memory processes by Ilex paraguariensis treatment as evaluated in mice

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Conferencia Internacionalsobre " Nuevos descubrimientos en el cérebro"

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:
Introduction: The ageing of the world population promotes an increase in prevalence of neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson´s diseases, among others CNS disorders, which leads to an urge in finding new therapies. One of the main features of these neurodegenerative diseases is the loss of memory. Thus, in order to solve or minimize this problem we have studied the use of an herbal product, Ilex paraguariensis, in attempt to affect learning and memory processes in an animal model. I. paraguariensis is a native plant species from South America, mostly found and socially used in Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay. It is popularly known as yerba mate and the infusion of its leaves is used to prepare a stimulant beverage (chimarrão, tererê or mate tea). Phytochemical profile of I. paraguariensis shows several constituents (flavonoids, cumarins, saponins and xanthines, mainly caffeine) that could be responsible for the alleged central effects. The present study aimed to investigate the effect of the aqueous (AE) and hydroethanolic (EHE) extracts of this plant species on the step-down passive avoidance test in mice.
Material & Methods: Adult male Swiss mice were acutely treated with AE, EHE (100 600 mg/kg. p.o.) or vehicle (saline solution) by gavage. After the oral treatment, animals were evaluated in the step down passive avoidance test. After a training session, the latency to step down from a platform was registered at 30 s, 90 min and 24h in order to investigate the extracts effects on the working, short- and long-term memories, respectively. Other groups were similarly treated and tested but animals were pretreated with scopolamine, a muscarinic cholinergic antagonist, capable of inducing transient memory impairment in normal subjects and used as an experimental model of Alzheimer's disease (AD). All experimental procedures were approved by the local Ethics Committee (23080.013794/2009-71/CEUA/UFSC) according to the international gu

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Reduction of plasmatic corticosterone and freezing behavior after central administration of NPY as evaluated in a contextual fear paradigm

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 21th Neuropharmacology Meeting - Anxietyt & Depression

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Neuropeptide Y (NPY) seems to be a promising target for treating anxiety and other psychiatric disorders because of its involvement in the behavioral consequences of stress. NPY acts with a high potency on a common core mechanism of emotionality and behavioral stress responses (Neuropeptides 38(4): 213-224, 2004). Based on this, we have evaluated the effects of NPY on the extinction of contextual fear memory in rats after fear conditioning. Male Wistar rats received a guide cannulae aimed at the lateral ventricule. After 7 days, rats were placed in the conditioning chamber for 3 min and received a 1-s electric foot shock (1.5 mA) for fear conditioning. Retrieval testing consisted of a 3-min exposure to the conditioning chamber and the extinction training consisted of three successive 9-min exposures at 24-h interval. NPY was administered always 5 min before de extinction test (5, 10 e 20nmol icv).. A no-drug test was performed, 24h later the last extinction session, to evaluate the lasting effect of NPY during the extinction session. Afterwards, rats were euthanized and the trunk blood collected for corticosterone analysis. NPY 10nmol inhibited freezing (NPY=27,15 4,42; 12,77 3,41/N=12; F=10.08 and p<0,05 X PBS=32,63 4,08; 23,53 4,70/N=11; F=2,74 and p>0,05) and the elevation of corticosterone (NPY=188,81 2,21/N=6 X PBS=197,45 2,64/N=4; t=2,48 and p<0,05), changed by the conditioning contextual fear. No effect was observed in other treatment group. NPY also did not show any anxiolytic effect in the no-drug session, indicating a selective effect in the extinction of the aversive memories in this paradigm. These findings, together with the literature correlating NPY with resilience in humans, led us to hypothetize that NPY may enhance the extinction of conditioned fear. Thus, the role of NPY in the extinction of conditioned fear may, at least in part, explain the mechanism underlying the association between NPY and psychobiological resilience in humans.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Strain differences in effects of social stress on territorial marking and body weight in mice
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Strain differences in effects of social stress on territorial marking and body weight in mice

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Neuroscience 2011

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Territorial urine marking (UM) is an important adaptive behavior in mice and other species. Acute social defeat stress elicits long-lasting deficits in mouse territoriality (Lumley et al., 1999). In the current study, the effects of prolonged social stress (6 hr/day x 10 days) on UM were evaluated during each 6 hr stress period. Subject mice (SD) were placed in a wire mesh box (14 x 18 x 9cm) inside an aggressor s (AGG) home cage (20 x 25 x 19cm), for 6hr/day x 10 days. At randomly-selected intervals, SD mice were placed in contact with AGG mice 2-3x/day for bouts lasting 1 min, or until 10 bites were received. Controls (C) were placed in a wire mesh box inside a (20 x 25 x 19cm) cage, for 6h/d x 10d, but had neither direct nor indirect exposure to AGG. SD and C were deprived of food and water during the 6 hr exposure. AGG were SJL strain. SD and C were C57BL/6, BALBc, or DBA/2 mouse strains. Mice were weighed each day prior to and after each 6h exposure. Filter paper was placed in the bottom of the mesh cages at the beginning of the 6hr period and subsequently analyzed for UM under exposure to UV light. Strain differences were observed among C mice. C57BL/6 C mice had greater marking relative to DBA/2 C and BALB/c C mice. Over the 10 day period, for C mice, C57 decreased UM, whereas BALBc and DBA both increased UM. For C57s, on day 1, SD displayed significantly less UM than C. C decreased UM over 10 days, and SD did not change, but there was still slightly less UM than C. For BALBc, on day 1, C and SD had similar UM; as C increased UM over time and SD did not, the difference at day 10 was significant. For DBA/2 mice, UM increased for both C and SD over 10 days. Body weight (AM) significantly increased over the 10 days in both C57 and BALBc mice but not in DBA/2 mice. In C57BL/6 mice, the AM (pre-stress) body weight tended to be greater in mice that had social stress over the 10 day period, relative to control. The current findings provide further data and support f

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Pharmacological validation of the non-convulsive pilocarpine-model of anxiety in rats as evaluated on the elevated plus-maze and open-field tests
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Pharmacological validation of the non-convulsive pilocarpine-model of anxiety in rats as evaluated on the elevated plus-maze and open-field tests

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: 8th IBRO World Congress of Neuroscience

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: The cholinergic system plays a main role in several brain functions, being involved in the underlying mechanisms of anxiety and epilepsy disorders. Even though pilocarpine (PILO) administration, a non-selective M1 agonist, resemble an experimental model of epilepsy, recent findings suggest that non-convulsive doses of this compound induces experimental anxiety in rats evaluated 24 h, 1 and 3 months after a single systemic injection (Duarte et al., 2010). Adult male Wistar rats were treated with saline (control group) or PILO (150 mg/kg) and 24 h later: 1) the behavior was evaluated in the elevated plus maze (EPM) and open-field (OF) tests and compared to pentylenetetrazole (PTZ, 15 mg/kg) or diazepam (DZP, 1 mg/kg) treatments, anxiogenic and anxiolytic standard drugs; 2) recordings (EEG) from hippocampus (HIP) and prefrontal cortex (PFC) were carried out to investigate possible seizure-like effects; 3) quantification of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) activity was performed PILO decreased the time spent (TOA%, t(14)=5.01; p<0.001) and entries on open arms (EOA%, t(14)=4.89; p<0.001) of the EPM when compared to control group, with no alterations in the number of crossed squares in the OF. DZP reverted PILO s effects on TOA% (F(2, 21)=39.34; p<0.00001) and EOA% (F(2, 21)=14.01; p<0.001). PILO did not elicited any seizure-like alterations on the EEG but an incidence of fast and low amplitude activity in the first hour. PTZ injection induced high amplitude and slow waves in HIP with no propagation to PFC in the first 30 min. PTZ injection in PILO-treated rats elicited low frequency and high amplitude discharge in both HIP and PFC. Moreover, PILO treatment decreased AChE activity in HIP (t(8)=2.59, p<0.05) when compared to control animals. Our findings suggest that the PILO model could be valid to study trait anxiety in rodents and may be helpful to better understand the role of cholinergic system on the modulation of anxiety-related disorders.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Social stress reduces mPFC volume and length of dendritic spines
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Social stress reduces mPFC volume and length of dendritic spines

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Biological Psychiatry

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Background: Chronic restraint decreases apical dendritic arborization, and chronic unpredictable stress decreases volume in rat medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC). Social stress (SS) robustly elicits long-lasting deficits in mouse territoriality and decreases dendritic spine (DS) density in mPFC. Methods: Subject (S), C57/B6 mouse, was placed in individual wire mesh box inside aggressor (AGG) home cage for 6h/d x 10d, without food or water. AGG was allowed direct contact with S 3x/d x 10d for bouts lasting 1 min or less. Controls (C) were treated similarly, but AGG never had contact with C. 24h after 10d stressor, S or C was placed for 5 min inside AGG home cage with grid barrier providing separation from AGG. 1h after barrier test, mice were killed by cervical dislocation, brains removed and Golgi impregnated. Results: SS mice persistently avoided barrier and showed restricted locomotion when near barrier. Volume decrease of 16% was shown stereologically in mPFC, and 27% reduction in DS length was seen in 2nd and higher order dendrites, with a shift from thin to a higher % stubby spines. Conclusions: Chronic SS induces avoidance of conspecifics, decreases mPFC volume and DS length, and alters DS spine type prevalence. Taken together, the results suggest SS model is relevant to PTSD.

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: O doutorando Gilliard Lach foi contemplado com um Travel Awards, sendo o único latino-americano dentre os selecionados pelo comitê executivo do evento.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: The ability of animals to minimize inappropriate responses following stressful events is called resilience. The absence of this successful adaptation facing a stressful experience may result in the development of psychiatric disorders (e.g. post-traumatic stress disorder [PTSD]). Animals exposed to environmental enrichment (EE) conditions are believed to present improved abilities related to the emotional response during stress, a sign of resilience. Pharmacologically, neuropeptide Y (NPY) administration has shown to increase resilience in both rodents and humans, facilitating the containment of negative consequences after the exposure to an unbearable situation. Based on the current knowledge, there is a lack of information regarding the involvement of the NPY system on EE-induced resilience. In this sense, we investigated the involvement of EE and NPY-Y1 receptor the major NPY receptor mediating emotional reactivity using biochemical and fear extinction analysis since extinction is usually impaired in non resilient patients who developed PTSD. Western blotting analysis showed that EE condition increases protein levels of NPY-Y1 in the hippocampus after the fear conditioning in rats when compared to those housed on the standard environment (SE). Regarding the effects of EE on the extinction of contextual fear conditioning paradigm (CFC), a Pavlovian conditioning, our results showed a facilitation of fear extinction, indicated by the reduction of freezing time, on the CFC in enriched animals compared with SE animals. Moreover, this facilitation was completely restored after the central injection of BIBO3304, a NPY-Y1 antagonist. These results prompt us to suggest that EE conditions could confer psychological resilience to CFC, by facilitating the extinction of fear, which may be underlied by an up-regulation of NPY-Y1 receptors.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: TAIL SUSPENSION TEST: STUDY OF BEHAVIORAL STRUCTURE IN MALE AND FEMALE SWISS MICE
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: TAIL SUSPENSION TEST: STUDY OF BEHAVIORAL STRUCTURE IN MALE AND FEMALE SWISS MICE

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: IBNS Annual Meeting 2013

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Depression is currently considered a life-threatening disease with a suicide rate of 15% among patients. Antidepressant drugs provide complete remission to about 50% of patients and cause several side-effects. Therefore, animal models of antidepressant activity are valuable tools to better understanding the neurobiology of this disorder and to evaluate new antidepressant drugs. The tail suspension test (TST) has been one of the most used tests for this kind of evaluation mainly because of its ease of use. However, this test still lacks sensitivity and specificity, often leading to false positive or negative results. We here studied if the evaluation of a wider catalog of behaviors could overcome these limitations. Thus, the aim of the present study was to evaluate the structure of the behavior of male and female Swiss mice submitted to TST (n=50) applying a catalog comprising active and passive behaviors over the 6 min of the duration of the test. Animals were divided into 5 groups of 10 mice and were treated with NaCl 0.9% (control group), antidepressant drugs (imipramine, desipramine and fluoxetine, 30mg/kg, IP) or with a motor stimulant (caffeine, 30mg/kg, IP) 30 min prior TST. The behaviors assessed in the TST were immobility (total absence of movement), flexed immobility (the animal remains motionless holding his paws or his tail), diffuse movement (non-repetitive movements in all possible directions) and rhythmic movement (repetitive pendular movements). A complete sampling was performed over the period of either test, generating frequencies and durations of the behaviors. For the data of male mice, the temporal analysis of behaviors in the TST showed that active behaviors were more prevalent in the first 2 min of the test when the passive postures started to increase. The profile presented by females subjected to this test has some special features, such as the frequency of flexed immobility is larger than in males, regardless the phase of the estrous cycle

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: O doutorando Alexandre Hoeller foi contemplado com um Travel Awards, sendo o único latino-americano dentre os 13 selecionados pelo comitê executivo do evento.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:
There is extensive evidence indicating the influence of the cholinergic system on emotional responses observed in human and animals. Our previous studies showed that a single systemic injection of a subconvulsant dose of pilocarpine - a non-selective muscarinic receptor agonist induces an anxiogenic-like profile in rats when evaluated at different behavioral tests of anxiety and time-points (24 h, 1 and 3 months later).
In order to better characterize and to shed light on the neural mechanisms mediating the effects induced by pilocarpine, adult male Wistar rats were treated with a subconvulsant dose of pilocarpine (PILO, i.p., 150 mg/kg), re-injected 24 h or 1 month later with GABA-A receptor modulators with anxiolytic (diazepam, DZP, i.p., 1 mg/kg) or anxiogenic (pentylenetetrazole, PTZ, i.p., 15 mg/kg) properties and evaluated in the elevated plus maze (EPM) apparatus. Electroencephalogram (EEG) and biochemical dosages of plasmatic corticosterone (CORT) and ACTH hormones were also performed shortly (24 h) or long-after (1 month) the treatment with pilocarpine.
In summary, anxiogenic-like responses were observed when rats were evaluated in the EPM test 24 h or 1 month after the injection of PILO, with a decrease in the time spent and number of entries on the open arms of the maze in comparison to control rats (treated with saline). Acute DZP injection blocked the anxiogenic-like effects observed in PILO-treated rats evaluated 24 h or 1 month after the treatment, increasing the time spent and number of entries on the open arms of the maze and altering the risk-assessment behaviors´ incidence. On the other hand, the acute injection of PTZ did not alter the behavioral profile of PILO-treated rats evaluated in the EPM test, suggesting the promotion of an anxiogenic top-response observed in this group. No epileptic-like events were observed during EEG recordings after the injection of PILO but an increase of theta activity in the hippocampus but not in the cor

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: O trabalho foi selecionado dentre os quase 40.000 trabalhos para apresentação oral no Nanosymposium - Mood Disorders: Stress and Animal Models of Depression.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Depression is currently considered a life-threatening disease, with a suicide rate of 15%. Antidepressant drugs provide complete remission to only about 50% of patients and cause several side effects. Therefore, animal models of antidepressant activity appear to be valuable tools to further understanding the neurobiology of disease and to evaluate new antidepressant drugs. The forced swimming test (FST) and the tail suspension test (TST) have been the most widely used tests for this type of evaluation mainly because of their ease of use. However, these tests still lack sensitivity and specificity. In order to overcome these limitations, in the present study we investigate the behavior structure of Swiss mice submitted to FST (n=50) or TST (n=50), applying a catalog comprising active and passive behaviors over the 6 min period of each test. Five groups of animals (N=10 ea) were treated with NaCl 0.9% (control) or standard antidepressant drugs (imipramine, desipramine and fluoxetine, 30mg/kg, IP) besides a motor stimulant drug (caffeine, 30mg/kg, IP) prior FST or TST. Behaviors assessed in TST were immobility (total absence of movement), flexed immobility (the animal remains motionless holding his paws or his tail, curling), diffuse movement (non-repetitive movements in all directions) and rhythmic movement (repetitive movements, swinging). For FST behaviors were: immobility, swimming and climbing. Frequencies and duration of each behavior were analyzed. Temporal analysis of behaviors in the FST and TST showed that active behaviors were more prevalent in the first 2 min whereas passive postures started to increase. Antidepressants and caffeine promoted a reduction on immobility time in TST and FST. However, caffeine and antidepressants affected different sets of active behaviors (desipramine was able to increase the time and frequency of rhythmic movement in TST; imipramine, increased the frequency of swimming in the FST and caffeine was the only treatment that enha

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Introduction: Failure on the regulation of responses to an acute stressor can lead to neurobiological alterations that can result in stress-related disorders (Olff, Langeland e Gersons, 2005). The prevalence of mood disorders related to stress is higher in women (Breslau, 2002; Kessler, 2003), which suggests a different response of neuroendocrine circuits involved in the response to stressful events (Carvalho-Netto et al., 2011). Aim: This study aimed to evaluate the behavioral patterns of two strains of mice, C57BL/6J and Swiss, when submitted to anxiety and depression-related tests, after an acute stressor. Methods: Male and female Swiss and C57BL/6J mice, three months old, were submitted to an acute stressor (30 min of cold restraint stress) one hour prior to the following tests: acoustic startle reflex (ASR), elevated plus maze (EPM) one week later, and tail suspension test (TST) another week later. Control group was naïve, not stressed, kept on their home cages. Data was analyzed by a three-way ANOVA followed by the Newman-Keuls post hoc test. Results: On TST we did not found any differences among sex, strain or groups. On the spatial-temporal measures of EPM we found that female C57BL/6J have a higher exploration indices of the open arms than female Swiss in both groups stressed and control [%OAE: F(1, 71)=9,4006, p< 0,05; %OAT: F(1, 70)=23,643, p< 0,05]. When we analyzed the time spent at the end of the open arms, the behavioral pattern was the same for females of both strains and there was a significant difference between males just in the stressed group[F(1, 71) = 4,4839, p < 0,05]. Among the ethological measures, the frequency of risk assessment was reduced in the C57BL/6J mice, in both groups of female mice and in the male stressed group [F(1, 71)=8,5238, p< 0,05]. Grooming, rearing and head dipping were unchanged in all groups. On ASR we found a difference for sex in the control group for C57BL/6J mice and on stressed group for Swiss mice [F(1, 72)=4,

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: In this study a mouse model is set up with a potentially unbiased platform to address the strain differences in response to social stress. Three different mouse strains of C57, BALB/c and DBA were submitted to 5 day and 10 day social stress (SS). Mice were kept inside an aggressor (AGG) home cage and randomly exposed to the AGG three times a day for one minute or for up to ten attacks in less than one minute, while control mice never experienced AGG proximity. Behavioral assessments were performed using the partition/barrier test. Behaviors were recorded and analyzed using Etho Vision software. Subject mice were kept in the aggressor cage separated from the aggressor by a perforated divider. Socially stressed mice persistently avoided the partition area that separated them from the aggressor mouse. C57 mice exhibited significant behavioral changes in response to stress. DBA strain mice showed lower susceptibility to SS than C57. When BABL/c mice were evaluated on the same scale of behavioral parameters, they showed intermediate levels of (SS) responses that were between the C57 and BALB/c responses. Genomic and epigenetic studies are underway to understand these differences in stress response.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Strain Differences in Responses to the Social Stress Model in the Mouse
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO-INGLES: Strain Differences in Responses to the Social Stress Model in the Mouse

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: Biological Psychiatry

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Background: Social stress (SS) appears to induce persistent fear, but not to same degree in all strains. Methods: We examined strain differences in behavioral responses to social stress, using a variation of the resident-intruder model. Mice of three different strains; C57, DBA and BALB/c, were subjected to 5 or 10 days of SS. Subject mouse was put in a small wire box which was placed inside an aggressor s (AGG) plastic home cage, and was randomly exposed to the AGG3 times per day for 1 min or up to 10 attacks. Controls (C) were housed in a similar environment, but were never exposed to physical attacks by AGGs. Twenty-four h after the final sessions, C or SS mouse was placed inside home cage of AGG for a 5 min partition test. Instead of being placed in a wire box, the subject was fully protected from the AGG by a perforated barrier that partitioned the plastic cage into 2 sections, thus allowing for full exposure to olfactory and visual cues, without physical contact. The subject s behaviors were recorded and analyzed using EthoVisionTM software. Results: While overall activity level was similar between C and SS groups, C57 mice subjected to SS demonstrated persistent avoidance of the barrier and retarded activity near AGG. In comparison, DBA showed a higher level of overall activity and lower susceptibility to SS effects during the partition test. BALB/c mice evaluated on the same behavioral parameters displayed responses to SS that were intermediate between the responses of the other two strains. Conclusions: SS elicited an inharmonious stress response across the subjects; individual differences in coping response lie at the core of vulnerability to stressors.

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: The ethanolic extract (EE) of Acosmium subelegans (Mohlenbr) Yakovl (perobinha-do-campo) was tested to behavioral paradigms in mice to investigate its putative central depressant effect. Oral pretreatment with the EE significantly reduced in a dose-dependent way the locomotor activity and increased by 30-55% the barbiturate sleep duration relatively to control values. At the highest dose (1,0 g.kg-1) it decreased the extension time/flexion time ratio of the maximal electroshockinduced convulsions, enhanced the latency to the pentylenetetrazol-induced convulsions and diminished by 26% the number of seizures, indicating an anticonvulsant action. No changes were observed in the motor coordination, the core temperature, climbing behavior, catalepsy and the plus-maze performance. The preliminary results indicate that the EE of A. subelegans induce a CNS depressant effect, more specifically an anticonvulsant effect that deserve a thorough investigation

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Nitric oxide involvement and neural substrates of the conditioned and innate fear as evaluated in the T-maze test in rats
GABAa signalling is involved in N/OFQ anxiolytic-like effects but not in nocistatin anxiogenic-like action as evaluated in the mouse elevated plus maze
Systemic administration of a nitric oxide synthase inhibitor impairs fear sensitization in the plus-maze
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Systemic administration of a nitric oxide synthase inhibitor impairs fear sensitization in the plus-maze

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: The aim of the present study was to evaluate the occurrence of fear sensitization in rats previously treated with an inhibitor of the NO syntheses and submitted to Trial1/Trial2 plus-maze (PM) procedure. Male Wistar rats received a systemic treatment with N(omega)-nitro-L-Arginine-methyl ester (L-NAME; 5, 10 or 50 mg kg(-1)) and were submitted to PM Trial1. In the following day the animals were re-exposed to the PM with no drug administration (Trial2). Some standards spatial-temporal measures, such as the percentage of entries (% Open arm entries) and time spent (% Open arm time) in the open arms and risk assessment frequency were recorded and used to estimate the animal level of fear sensitization in PM Trial2. The results showed that animals receiving L-NAME (50 mg kg(-1)) displayed increased % Open arm entries and % Open arm time in Trial2 in relation to the group receiving 0.9% saline, which is compatible with impaired fear/anxiety acquisition during Trial1/Trial2 PM procedure. In addition, rats treated with L-NAME (50 mg kg(-1)) exhibited low level of risk assessment in Trial2 in relation to the group treated with 0.9% saline, which indicates low level of fear/anxiety during PM re-exposure. The number of entries into the enclosed arms was not changed by any L-NAME treatment, which suggests no bias of the drug treatments on animal locomotor activity. The data suggest that NO synthesis may mediate the fear sensitization process in the PM.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Frequency of climbing behavior as a predictor of altered motor activity in rat forced swimming test

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Previous work has shown that the frequency of climbing behavior in rats submitted to the forced swimming test (FST) correlated to the section s crosses in the open field test, which suggest it might be taken as a predictor of motor activity in rat FST. To investigate this proposal, the frequency, duration, as well as the ratio duration/frequency for each behavior expressed in the FST (immobility, swimming and climbing) were compared in animals treated with a motor stimulant, caffeine (CAF), and the antidepressant, clomipramine (CLM). Male Wistar rats were submitted to 15 min of forced swimming (pre-test) and 24 h later received saline (SAL, 1 ml/kg, i.p.) or CAF (6.5 mg/kg, i.p.) 30 min prior a 5-min session (test) of FST. To validate experimental procedures, an additional group of rats received three injections of SAL (1 ml/kg, i.p.) or clomipramine (CLM, 10 mg/kg, i.p.) between the pre-test and test sessions. The results of the present study showed that both drugs, CLM and CAF, significantly reduced the duration of immobility and significantly increased the duration of swimming. In addition, CAF significantly decreased the ratio of immobility, and CLM significantly increased the ratio of swimming and climbing. Moreover, CLM significantly increased the duration of climbing but only CAF increased the frequency of climbing. Thus, it seems that the frequency of climbing could be a predictor of altered motor activity scored directly in the FST. Further, we believe that this parameter could be useful for fast and reliable discrimination between antidepressant drugs and stimulants of motor activity.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Neuropharmacological Activity of the Pericarp of Passiflora edulis flavicarpa Degener: Putative Involvement of C-Glycosylflavonoids
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Neuropharmacological Activity of the Pericarp of Passiflora edulis flavicarpa Degener: Putative Involvement of C-Glycosylflavonoids

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Experimental Biology and Medicine (Maywood, N.J.: Print)

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Short- and long-term anxiogenic effects induced by a single injection of non convulsive doses of pilocarpine: investigation of the putative role of hippocampal pathways
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Short- and long-term anxiogenic effects induced by a single injection of sub convulsant doses of pilocarpine: investigation of the putative role of hippocampal pathways

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Rationale: The behavioral consequences of convulsive episodes are already well documented in rodents but less attention has been paid to the behavioral changes that may occur in response to subconvulsant doses of drugs. Objectives: We investigated the short and long-term effects of a single systemic injection of subconvulsant doses of pilocarpine on the behavior of rats as evaluated in the elevated plus-maze (EPM). The putative role of hippocampal output pathways in the behavioral alterations observed after pilocarpine treatment was also studied. Methods and Results: Subconvulsant doses of pilocarpine induced an anxiogenic-like profile in rats tested 24 h later in the EPM and this effect persisted for up three months. The temporary inactivation of the fimbria-fornix with lidocaine 4% promoted an anxiolytic-like effect per se, suggesting a tonic control of this pathway on the modulation of anxiety-related behaviors. Lidocaine also reduced the anxiogenic-like profile of animals tested one month after pilocarpine treatment. In order to determine whether the anxiogenic-like effect was mediated by the septal region or by direct hippocampal projections to the diencephalon, we also blocked the neural transmission of the post-commissural fornix. A similar reduction in the anxiogenic-like effect of pilocarpine was observed when we blocked this pathway. Conclusions: Our findings suggest that a single systemic injection of pilocarpine at a non-convulsive dose may induce long lasting anxiogenic-like behavior in rats and this effect appears to be mediated, at least in part, through a direct path from the hippocampus to medial hypothalamic sites involved in fear responses.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Involvement of GABAergic non-benzodiazepine sites in the anxiolytic-like and sedative effects of the flavonoid baicalein in mice
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Involvement of GABAergic non-benzodiazepine sites in the anxiolytic-like and sedative effects of the flavonoid baicalein in mice

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Baicalein (BA), one of the main flavonoids obtained from the Chinese medicinal herb Scutellaria baicalensis, usually exerts several pharmacological effects. In the central nervous system (CNS), BA exerts a protective effect on neurons against several neuronal insults among other effects, but it is not clear if this effect is due to its metabolite, baicalin. The purpose of the present study was to assess the anxiolytic-like and related properties of BA following its central administration (i.c.v.) in mice. BA (0.02, 0.2 pmol) exerted an anxiolytic-like effect at low doses, increasing the time spent in open arms and the head-dipping whereas reducing the stretched-attend postures in the elevated plus-maze. BA also increased the duration of ether-induced sleep without affecting the pentylenetetrazol (PTZ)-induced convulsions. In addition, pretreatment with flumazenil (FMZ), PTZ, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS), and dl-p-chlorophenilalanine ethyl ester (PCPA) were conducted in order to investigate its mechanism of action. PTZ and DHEAS, but not FMZ or PCPA, antagonized the BA s anxiolytic-like effect. Taken together our results showed that BA, when directly injected into the CNS, promotes anxiolytic-like and sedative effects, pharmacological activities dependent on GABAergic non-benzodiazepine sites but not on the 5-HT system.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Anxiolytic-like effect of central administration of NOP receptor antagonist UFP-101 in rats submitted to the elevated T-maze
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Anxiolytic-like effect of central administration of NOP receptor antagonist UFP-101 in rats submitted to the elevated T-maze

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Depression and anxiety disorders present several genetic and neurobiological similarities. Drugs with antidepressant activity are effective in the treatment of a wide spectrum of anxiety disorders. Preclinical results showed that acute and chronic treatment with the NOP antagonist [Nphe1,Arg14,Lys15]N/OFQ-NH2 (UFP-101) produced antidepressant-like effects in rodents. Thus, the present study aimed to investigate the effect of central administration of UFP-101 on the anxiety-related behavior in rats as evaluated in the elevated T-maze (ETM) test. Our results showed that UFP-101 reduced the latency of inhibitory avoidance in the ETM, indicating an anxiolytic-like effect. The endogenous peptide N/OFQ prevented this anxiolytic-like action of UFP-101, demonstrating its modulation via central NOP receptors. However, UFP-101 failed to interfere with the latency to escape. No change was observed in locomotor activity after UFP-101 treatment, ruling out any nonspecific motor effect. In conclusion, our results showed that the central administration of UFP-101 presents an anxiolytic-like effect in rats evaluated in the ETM test, providing new insights for drug development to treat anxiety disorders targeting the N/OFQ-NOP receptor system.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Effects of social isolation and enriched environment on behavior of adult Swiss mice do not require hippocampal neurogenesis
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Effects of social isolation and enriched environment on behavior of adult Swiss mice do not require hippocampal neurogenesis

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Housing conditions are important determinants of animal behavior. Their impact on behavioral output depends on the behavior of interest, species, strain, and age of the animal evaluated. In the present study, male Swiss mice reared from weaning up to 8 weeks in social isolation (SI8), in enriched environment (EE8) or in standard environment (SE8) were evaluated in the elevated plus-maze (EPM), open-field (OFT) and tail-suspension (TST) tests. The effect of housing for six weeks in EE followed by 2 weeks in SI (EE6SI2) and the opposite condition (SI6EE2) were also studied. Housing conditions are reported to affect hippocampal neurogenesis; therefore, the expression of doublecortin (DCX) in the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus (DG) of these mice was monitored. Data showed that SI8, EE8 and EE6SI2 reduced the stretching-attend postures in the EPM and explored more the center of the apparatus when compared to SE8. The time and the number of entries in the closed arms of the EPM was not affected indicating that effects of housing conditions in the EPM were not consequence of motor activity alteration. Accordingly, EE8 mice exploration of the OFT was similar to SE8. However, the SI8 mice explored the OFT more than the EE8 mice, suggesting hyperactivity induced by isolation. Behavior of Swiss mice in the TST was not altered, indicating that this test was not sensitive to the environmental changes in this mice strain. Compared to SE8, EE8 did not affect the number of DCX cells, whereas SI8, EE6SI2, and SI6EE2 decreased it. Taken together, our data suggest that the behavior of adult Swiss mice in the EPM and OFT was affected by environmental changes but that these changes seem to be independent of hippocampal neurogenesis.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Anti-inflammatory and opioid-like activities in methanol extract of Mikania lindleyana, sucuriju
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Anti-inflammatory and opioid-like activities in methanol extract of Mikania lindleyana, sucuriju

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Mikania lindleyana (sucuriju) grows in the Amazon Region, where is frequently used to pain, inflammatory diseases and scarring. This study was carried out to investigate phytochemical profile accompanied by in vivo antinociceptive and antiinflamatory screening of hexane (HE), dichloromethane (DME) and methanol (ME) extracts obtained from the aerial parts of the plant. The oral administration of ME (0.1 1 g/kg) caused a dose-related reduction of acetic acid-induced writhing response (ID50 = 431.5 mg/kg) while HE and DME (1 g/kg, p.o.) were ineffective. In the hot plate test, ME (300 mg/kg, p.o.) increased the latency of heat stimulus between 30 and 120 min and inhibited the first (45 %) and second (60 %) phases of nociception in the formalin test. The antinociception induced by ME or positive control fentanyl (100 g/kg, s.c.) in hot plate and formalin tests was prevented by naloxone (3 mg/kg, s.c.). When submitted to the carrageenan-induced peritonitis test, ME (0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 g/kg, p.o.) impaired leukocyte migration into the peritoneal cavity by 46.8, 59.4 and 64.8%, respectively while positive control dexamethasone (2 mg/kg, s.c.), inhibited leukocyte migration by 71.1%. These results indicate that the potent antinociception obtained after oral administration of methanol extract of Mikania lindleyana involves antiinflammatory mechanisms accompanied with opioid-like activity which could explain the use of the plant for pain and inflammatory diseases.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Central pharmacological activity of a new piperazine derivative: 4-(1-Phenyl-1h-pyrazol-4-ylmethyl)-piperazine-1-carboxylic acid ethyl ester
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Central pharmacological activity of a new piperazine derivative: 4-(1-Phenyl-1h-pyrazol-4-ylmethyl)-piperazine-1-carboxylic acid ethyl ester

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: AIMS: Our study focuses on the design and synthesis of a new piperazinic derivate, 4-(1-phenyl-1h-Pyrazol-4-Ylmethyl)-Piperazine-1-Carboxylic Acid Ethyl ester (LQFM008), and evaluation of its anxiolytic-like profile in Swiss mice. MAIN METHODS: LQFM008 was evaluated in a screening test of the central nervous system including the rota-rod, sodium pentobarbital-induced sleep, open field, elevated plus maze and light-dark box tests. KEY FINDINGS: LQFM008 induced convulsions at the dose of 1.1mmol/kg (i.p., s.c. or p.o.). LQFM008 up to 400μmol/kg had no effect in the rota rod test. In the open field test, LQFM008 increased the number of crossings and the time spent at the central area as well as the sleeping time in sodium pentobarbital-induced sleep. In the elevated plus maze and light-dark box tests, this compound showed an anxiolytic-like activity. This anxiolytic-like activity was antagonized by NAN-190 (5-HT(1A) antagonist) but not by flumazenil (benzodiazepine antagonist). SIGNIFICANCE: The compound LQFM008 showed anxiolytic-like activity which may involve serotonergic pathway.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Murine Model of Repeated Exposures to Conspecific Trained Aggressors Simulates Features of Post-traumatic Stress Disorder
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Murine Model of Repeated Exposures to Conspecific Trained Aggressors Simulates Features of Post-traumatic Stress Disorder

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: We evaluated repeated exposures of mice to a trained aggressor mouse as a model (adapted from social stress models of traumatic stress) for aspects of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Using a cage-in-cage resident-intruder protocol, subject C57BL/6J mice were exposed to aggressors for six hours daily for five or 10 days. At one to three random times during each six-hour session, subjects were exposed directly to aggressor for one minute or 10 bites, whichever came first. Behavioral, physiological, and histological changes associated with aggressor-exposure were assessed for up to six weeks. During aggressor exposure, subjects displayed less territorial behavior, gained weight, and increased body temperature. One day after the last aggressor exposure, heart cardiac inflammatory histopathologies were prevalent; after 10 days, only mild myocardial degeneration with fibrosis or fibroplasias was evident, while controls showed almost no cardiac abnormalities at any time. After four weeks, the medial prefrontal cortex of control mice showed increased dendritic spine density, but aggressor-exposed mice showed no increase. Behaviors affected by aggressor exposure were evaluated in a partition test wherein the subject mouse is separated from the aggressor by a fenestrated partition that permits sensory cues to pass but prevents direct physical interaction. For up to four to six weeks after the last aggressor exposure, subjects showed prolonged grooming, freezing, retarded locomotion and no tail rattling. PTSD and its co-morbidities are often consequent to repeated aggravated social assaults (e.g., combat) and manifest socially over time, suggesting the relevance of this repeated aggressor-exposure model to clinical aspects of PTSD.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Evaluation of analgesic and anti-inflammatory activities of Hydrocotyle umbellata L., Araliaceae (acariçoba) in mice
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Evaluation of analgesic and anti-inflammatory activities of Hydrocotyle umbellata L., Araliaceae (acariçoba) in mice

DETALHAMENTO-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-PERIODICO-OU-REVISTA: Anais da Academia Brasileira de Ciências (Impresso)

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: The Hydrocotyle umbellata L. is a specimen of the Araliaceae family popularly known as acariçoba. Its indications in folk medicine include treatment of skin ulcers, and rheumatism. The aim of this study was to evaluate the antinociceptive and antiinflammatory activities of the ethanolic extract from acariçoba s underground parts (EEA). EEA reduced the nociceptive response of the animals as evaluated in the acetic acid-induced writhing test and in both phases of formalin test. EEA also presented a supraspinal analgesic activity by increasing the pain latency in the hot plate test. Moreover, EEA reduced the leukocytes migration and plasma extravasation into pleural cavity in the carrageenan-induced pleurisy besides reducing the edema induced by carrageenan or dextran up to the second hour. Altogether, our results showed that EEA of H. umbellata presents analgesic and anti-inflammatory activities, and that a blockade of activity or reduction in the release of different mediators, such as histamine and serotonin, could be involved in these pharmacologic effects.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: The anxiolytic-like effect of an essential oil derived from Spiranthera odoratissima A. St. Hil. leaves and its major component, beta-caryophyllene, in male mice
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: The anxiolytic-like effect of an essential oil derived from Spiranthera odoratissima A. St. Hil. leaves and its major component, beta-caryophyllene, in male mice

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES:
Spiranthera odoratissima A. St. Hil. (manacá) is used in folk medicine to treat renal and hepatic diseases, stomachache, headaches and rheumatism. A central nervous system (CNS) depressant effect of the hexane fraction from the ethanolic extract of this plant has been described. β-caryophyllene, the main component of this essential oil, is a sesquiterpene compound with anti-inflammatory properties that has been found in essential oils derived from several medicinal plants.
This work is aimed to evaluate the pharmacological activity of the essential oil obtained from S. odoratissima leaves (EO) and its major component on the murine CNS; we aimed to evaluate a possible anxiolytic-like effect and the underlying mechanisms involved. In an open field test, EO (500 mg/kg) and β-caryophyllene (50, 100 and 200 mg/kg) increased the crossing frequency (P < 0.05) and, EO (250 and 500 mg/kg) and β-caryophyllene (200 mg/kg) increased the time spent in the center (P < 0.05) without altering total crossings of the open field. EO and β-caryophyllene did not alter the number of falls in the rota-rod test (P > 0.05). In the pentobarbital-induced sleep test, EO (500 mg/kg) and β-caryophyllene (200 and 400 mg/kg) decreased the latency to sleep (P < 0.05), and EO (125, 250 and 500 mg/kg) (P < 0.001) and β-caryophyllene (200 and 400 mg/kg) (P < 0.05 and P < 0.001) increased the sleep time. In anxiety tests, EO (500 mg/kg) and β-caryophyllene (100 and 200 mg/kg) increased head-dipping behavior (P < 0.05) in the hole-board test, entries (P < 0.05) into and time spent (P < 0.05) on the open arms of the elevated plus maze (EPM), and number of transitions (P < 0.05) and time spent in the light compartment (P < 0.05) of a light dark box (LDB). We further investigated the mechanism of action underlying the anxiolytic-like effect of EO and β-caryophyllene by pre-treating animals with antagonists of benzodiazepine (flumazenil) and 5-HT1A (NAN-190) recept

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Quantitative changes of nicotinic receptors in the hippocampus of dystrophin-deficient mice

AUTORES.NOME-COMPLETO-DO-AUTOR: Maria Teresa Riggio de Lima Landman

DE LIMA, THEREZA;LIMA, THEREZA CHRISTINA MONTEIRO DE;DE LIMA, THEREZA C. MONTEIRO;LIMA, T.C.M.;DE LIMA, TC;DE LIMA. T.C.M.;DE LIMA, THEREZA C.M.;DE-LIMA, T.C.M.;LIMA, THEREZA C.M. DE

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: NMDA Preconditioning Attenuates Cortical and Hippocampal Seizures Induced by Intracerebroventricular Quinolinic Acid Infusion

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Searching for new therapeutic strategies through modulation of glutamatergic transmission by using effective neuroprotective agents is essential. Glutamatergic excitotoxicity is a common factor to neurodegenerative diseases and acute events such as cerebral ischemia, traumatic brain injury and epilepsy. This study aimed to evaluate behavioral and electroencephalographic (EEG) responses of mice cerebral cortex and hippocampus to sub-convulsant and convulsant application of NMDA and quinolinic acid (QA), respectively. Morevover, it aimed to evaluate if EEG responses may be related to the neuroprotective effects of NMDA. Mice were preconditioned with NMDA (75 mg/kg, i.p.) and EEG recordings were performed for 30 min. One day later, QA was injected (36.8 nmol/site) and EEG recordings were performed during 10 min. EEG analysis demonstrated NMDA preconditioning promotes spike-wave discharges (SWD), but, it does not display behavioral manifestation of seizures. Animals that were protected by NMDA preconditioning against QA-induced behavioral seizures, presented higher number of SWD after NMDA administration, in comparison to animals preconditioned with NMDA that did display behavioral seizures after QA infusion. No differences were observed in latency for the first seizure or duration of seizures. EEG recordings after QA infusion, demonstrated there were no differences in the number of SWD, latency for the first seizure or duration of seizures in animals pretreated with saline or in animals preconditioned by NMDA that received QA. A negative correlation was identified between the number of NMDA-induced SWD and QA-induced seizures severity. These results suggest a higher activation during NMDA preconditioning diminishes mice probability to display behavioral seizures after QA infusion.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Ghrelin as a Neuroprotective and Palliative Agent in Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Disease
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Ghrelin as a Neuroprotective and Palliative Agent in Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Disease

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Ghrelin is a gastric hormone that stimulates growth hormone (GH) secretion and food intake to regulate energy homeostasis and body weight by binding to its receptor, GH secretagogue receptor (GHSR1a), which is most highly expressed in the pituitary and hypothalamus. Nowadays there is considerable evidence showing that the GHSR1a is also expressed in numerous extra-hypothalamic neuronal populations and the physiological role of ghrelin is by far wider than considered before including learning and memory, anxiety, depression and neuroprotection. The present review attempts to provide a comprehensive picture of the role of ghrelin in the central nervous system and to highlight recent findings showing its potential as an innovative therapeutic agent in neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer s and Parkinson s diseases.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Ghrelin is a gastric hormone that stimulates growth hormone (GH) secretion and food intake to regulate energy homeostasis and body weight by binding to its receptor, GH secretagogue receptor (GHSR1a), which is most highly expressed in the pituitary and hypothalamus. Nowadays there is considerable evidence showing that the GHSR1a is also expressed in numerous extra-hypothalamic neuronal populations and the physiological role of ghrelin is by far wider than considered before including learning and memory, anxiety, depression and neuroprotection. The present review attempts to provide a comprehensive picture of the role of ghrelin in the central nervous system and to highlight recent findings showing its potential as an innovative therapeutic agent in neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer s and Parkinson s diseases.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Anxiogenic-like profile of Wistar adult rats based on the pilocarpine model: an animal model for trait anxiety?

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: There is extensive evidence indicating the influence of seizures on emotional responses observed in human and animals, but so far few studies focusing on the behavioral profile of animals that do not have seizures despite being treated with convulsant agents. Objectives: We aimed to establish the behavioral profile, biochemical and electrographic features of rats submitted to the pilocarpine model of temporal lobe epilepsy. Methods: Rats treated with pilocarpine (20 to 350 mg/kg; i.p.) that did not develop status epilepticus or spontaneous recurrent seizures were evaluated 1 month later in the elevated plus-maze (EPM), T-maze (ETM), open-field (OF) and step-down avoidance tests. Electroencephalographic (EEG), glutamate uptake and hippocampal neuronal death assays were also performed Results: Pilocarpine (150 or 350 mg/kg) promoted anxiogenic-like effects in rats evaluated in the EPM, ETM and OF tests whereas only the highest dose evoked spike-wave discharges during EEG recordings. Hippocampal theta rhythm was increased by pilocarpine 150 or 350 mg/kg and only the highest dose reduced the L-[3H]-glutamate uptake and cell viability on hippocampal slices. Conclusions: Subconvulsant doses of pilocarpine promote long-lasting alterations on neural circuitry, reflected by an increased theta activity in the hippocampus and an anxiety-like profile of rats evaluated 1 month after the treatment which is independent of seizure occurrence and is not related to changes in glutamate uptake or hippocampal damage. These results prompt us to suggest that a systemic administration of subconvulsant doses of pilocarpine could be useful as a new tool to model trait anxiety in rats.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Phytochemical profile, toxicity and antioxidant activity of Aloysia gratissima (Verbenaceae)
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Phytochemical profile, toxicity and antioxidant activity of Aloysia gratissima (Verbenaceae)

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Aloysia gratissima (Gill. et Hook) Tronc. (Verbenaceae) is native to South America with folk therapeutic applications for a wide range of diseases. The polyphenolic and carotenoid profile, toxicity, and antioxidant activity of aqueous extract of Aloysia gratissima were investigated. HPLC analyses showed high amounts of ferulic acid, trans-cinnamic acid and p-coumaric acid, and also transb-carotene and lutein which fluctuated throughout the seasons. Furthermore, the extract investigated not only exerted antioxidant activity but also inhibited lipid peroxidation. Toxicity was achieved only at the highest dose tested. Therefore, A. gratissima is a potential species for medicinal purposes.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Neuropeptide Y (NPY) prevents depressive-like behavior, spatial memory deficits and oxidative stress following amyloid-β (Aβ1 40) administration in mice
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Neuropeptide Y (NPY) prevents depressive-like behavior, spatial memory deficits and oxidative stress following amyloid-β (Aβ1 40) administration in mice

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-2: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Neuropeptide Y (NPY) is a 36-amino acid peptide widely distributed in the central nervous system (CNS) that has been associated with the modulation of several functions including food intake, learning and memory, mood and neuroprotection. There is great interest in understanding the role of NPY in the deleterious effects induced by the central accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) peptides, a pathological hallmark of Alzheimer s disease (AD). Herein, we evaluated the effects of a single intracerebroventricular (i.c.v.) administration of NPY (0.0234 μmol/μl) 15 min prior to the i.c.v. injection of aggregated Aβ1-40 peptide (400 pmol/mouse) in behavioral and neurochemical parameters related to oxidative stress in mice. Pretreatment with NPY prevented Aβ1-40-induced depressive-like responses and spatial memory impairments evaluated in the tail suspension and object location tasks, respectively. The protective effects of NPY on spatial memory of Aβ1-40-treated mice were abolished by the pretreatment with the selective Y2 receptor antagonist BIIE0246. On the other hand, the administration of NPY and Aβ1-40 did not alter the performance of the animals in the elevated plus-maze and open field arena, indicating lack of effects on anxiety state and locomotor function. Although Aβ1-40 infusion did not change hippocampal and cortical glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activity and glutathione (GSH) levels, Aβ1 40-infused animals showed an increased lipid peroxidation in hippocampus and prefrontal cortex that were blunted by NPY administration. These findings indicate that central administration of NPY prevents Aβ1-40-induced depressive-like behavior and spatial memory deficits in mice and that this response is mediated, at least in part, by the activation of Y2 receptors and prevention of oxidative stress.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Role of NPY Y1 Receptor on Acquisition, Consolidation and Extinction on Contextual Fear Conditioning: Dissociation Between Anxiety, Locomotion and non Emotional Memory Behavior

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Neuropeptide Y (NPY) is the most abundant peptide in the central nervous system (CNS) and is densely localized in the brain regions involved in stress, memory, fear and anxiety. Although previous research supports a role for NPY in the mediation of rodent and human emotional behavior, there is currently a lack of information on the effects of low doses of NPY that could have a potential therapeutic advantage, minimizing side-effects such as cognition impairment or sedation. Herein, we assessed the effects of intracerebroventricular (i.c.v.) administration of low doses of NPY, and of the Y1-agonist Leu31Pro34-NPY (LP-NPY) on contextual fear conditioning (CFC), as they have no effect on unconditioned anxiety-like, locomotor activity and non-emotional memory. NPY (3 pmol) and LP-NPY (1 pmol) inhibited freezing behavior when administered in the acquisition or consolidation stages, indicating a reduction of fear. When injected in the extinction phase, only NPY inhibited freezing behavior on CFC. Pre-treatment with the Y1-antagonist BIBO3304 before NPY and LP-NPY was able to prevent the inhibition of fear responses induced by both NPY agonists. Taken together, our results demonstrate robust fear-inhibiting effects of i.c.v. injection of NPY on contextual fear conditioning in rats, a response that is mediated, at least in part, by the Y1 receptor. Moreover, these treatments were unable to change locomotor activity or to show an anxiolytic-like effect, as evaluated in an open-field and an elevated plus-maze. This specific fear reduction effect may underlie resilience systems in the CNS and has potential therapeutic relevance in PTSD.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Role of ventral hippocampal nitric oxide/cGMP pathway in anxiety-related behaviors in rats submitted to the elevated T-maze
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: Role of ventral hippocampal nitric oxide/cGMP pathway in anxiety-related behaviors in rats submitted to the elevated T-maze

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The l-arginine/nitric oxide (NO)/cGMP pathways have been implicated in the control of a variety of physiological mechanisms and are believed to participate in the modulation of anxiety in the CNS. The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of NG-nitro-l-arginine-methyl-ester (l-NAME), a non-selective inhibitor of NO synthase (NOS); 7-nitroindazole (7-NI), a preferential inhibitor of neuronal NOS; and sodium nitroprusside (SNP), an NO donor, administered into the ventral hippocampus (VH) of rats submitted to the elevated T-maze (ETM). The ETM, an animal model derived from the elevated plus-maze, allows the measurement of two defensive behavioral responses in the same rat: inhibitory avoidance and escape. Results showed that l-NAME and 7-NI impaired the acquisition of inhibitory avoidance and prolonged escape latency in the ETM, suggesting an anxiolytic-like and panicolytic-like effect, respectively. SNP facilitated the acquisition of inhibitory avoidance without interfering with escape performance, suggesting an anxiogenic-like effect. Treatment with methylene blue did not alter per se any of the behavioral responses measured in the ETM, but blocked the effect promoted by SNP. Thus, altogether these results suggest that NO in the VH is critically involved in the modulation of defensive behavior of rats exposed to the ETM.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: A proposal for refining the forced swim test in Swiss mice
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: A proposal for refining the forced swim test in Swiss mice

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The forced swim test (FST) is a preclinical test to the screening of antidepressants based on rats or mice behaviours, which is also sensitive to stimulants of motor activity. This work standardised and validated a method to register the active and passive behaviours of Swiss mice during the FST in order to strength the specificity of the test. Adult male Swiss mice were subjected to the FST for 6 min without any treatment or after intraperitoneal injection of saline (0.1 ml/10 g), or antidepressants (imipramine, desipramine, or fluoxetine, 30 mg/kg) or stimulants (caffeine, 30 mg/kg or apomorphine, 10 mg/kg). The latency, frequency and duration of behaviours (immobility, swimming, and climbing) were scored and summarised in bins of 6, 4, 2 or 1 min. Parameters of untreated mice were analysed using a Principal Components Analysis generating components putatively related to antidepressant (first and second) or to stimulant effects (third). Indeed, antidepressants and stimulants affected similarly the parameters correlated to all components. Effects of stimulants on climbing were better distinguished of antidepressants when analysed during the last 4 min of the FST. Surprisingly, the effects of antidepressants on immobility were more strongly distinguished from saline when parameters were scored in the first 2 min. The method proposed here is able to distinguish antidepressants from stimulants of motor activity using Swiss mice in the FST. This refinement should reduce the number of mice used in preclinical evaluation of antidepressants.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: GABA-A receptor modulators alter emotionality and hippocampal theta rhythm in an animal model of long-lasting anxiety
DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO-INGLES: GABA-A receptor modulators alter emotionality and hippocampal theta rhythm in an animal model of long-lasting anxiety

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades de atenção à saúde humana

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The cholinergic system plays a main role on anxiety and epilepsy disorders. Previous results showed that an injection of a non-convulsive dose of pilocarpine (PILO) - a non-selective M1 agonist induces enhanced aversion in rats when evaluated at different time-points (24 h, 1 and 3 months later) on models of anxiety. In order to validate this paradigm and to shed light into physiological and biochemical events mediating the aversion induced by PILO, in the present study adult male Wistar rats were treated with saline (SAL) or PILO (150 mg/kg) and 24 h later: 1) the behavioral was evaluated on the elevated plus maze (EPM) and open-field (OF) tests after pretreatment with SAL, pentylenetetrazole (PTZ, 15 mg/kg) or diazepam (DZP, 1 mg/kg); 2) Possible seizure-like effects were investigated by electroencephalographic (EEG) recordings on hippocampus (HIP) and prefrontal cortex (PFC); and 3) quantification of HIP and PFC acetylcholinesterase (AChE) activity. In summary, PILO decreased the time spent and number of entries on open arms of the maze when compared to control group. DZP pretreatment mitigated PILO-induced anxiogenic-like effects whereas PTZ had no significant effects. PILO did not elicit seizure-like alterations on EEG although PTZ induced high amplitude and slow waves in HIP. Moreover, PILO decreased AChE activity in HIP when compared to control animals. In conclusion, our findings support the proposal of the non-convulsive PILO model as a valid paradigm to study trait anxiety in rodents which can be helpful to better understand the cholinergic role on the modulation of anxiety-related disorders.
